{{Other uses2|Argo}} {{Infobox web browser | name = Argo | logo = | screenshot = [[File:Argo.gif|200px]] | caption = | author = | developer = [[Bert Bos]]<ref name="WWW3" /> | released = <!--{{release date and age|1993}}--> | latest release version = | latest release date = <!--{{release date and age|1997|07|02}}--> | operating system =[[HP-UX]] | platform = | language = English | programming language = | genre = [[web browser]] | license = [[W3C Software Notice and License]]<!--<ref group="a">Insert footnote text here</ref>-->/[[CERN]] [[open source]] copyright | discontinued = yes | website = }} '''Argo''' was part of a project to make the [[Internet]] accessible to scholars in the Humanities at the [[University of Groningen]].<ref name="chapter20" /> The Argo [[web browser]] was created in August 1994 by [[Bert Bos]].<ref name="WWW3">{{Cite web|title=SIMPLE STYLE SHEETS FOR SGML & HTML ON THE WEB|url=http://www.w3.org/People/Bos/style.html|publisher=[[World Wide Web Consortium]]|accessdate=20 June 2010|author=[[Bert Bos]]|date=14 April 1995}}</ref>
There currently is no publicly available compiled version, although the source code still exists.<ref>[http://www.w3.org/People/Bos/Argo/browser/argo/ the download directory for the Argo files]</ref>
==History== The Argo browser was able to handle its own [[style sheet language]] called [[Stream-based Style Sheet Proposal]] (SSP) [[Rendering (computer graphics)|rendered]] mostly by [[Xlib]]/[[Xrm]].<ref name="WWW3"/> SSP was general enough to be able to applied to other [[markup language]]s in addition to [[HTML]]. In the development process of [[Cascading Style Sheets]] (CSS) Bos was one of the first people who decided to join [[HÃ¥kon Wium Lie]].<ref name="chapter20">{{Cite web|title=Chapter 20 - The CSS saga|url=http://www.w3.org/Style/LieBos2e/history/|publisher=[[World Wide Web Consortium]]|accessdate=23 June 2010|author=[[HÃ¥kon Wium Lie]]|coauthors=[[Bert Bos]]}}</ref> Although this early adoption SSP had other advanced features that could not be integrated in CSS1 and had to wait for CSS2.<ref name="chapter20" /> [[Arena (web browser)|Arena]] and Argo were presented as a [[testbed]] at the [[World Wide Web Conference 3]] on 10â14 April 1995 in [[Darmstadt]]<ref name="WWW3" /><ref name="chapter20" />
==Functionality== Argo based on the [[W3A]], an [[Application programming interface|API]] for ''WWW browser applets''.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Home Page of Bert Bos|url=http://www.w3.org/People/Bos/|publisher=[[World Wide Web Consortium]]|accessdate=27 June 2010|author=[[Bert Bos]]}}</ref> The browser featured [[Plug-in (computing)|plug-in]] modules, or "[[applets]]", which allowed for the addition of new functionality without recompilation. Examples of such functionality provided by the applets includes adding support for the following:<ref name="WWW3" />
* [[Internet bookmark|Bookmarks]]/history * [[Cache]]/[[Proxy server|proxy]] support * [[File format|Data formats]] (e.g. [[ASCII]], [[GIF]], [[HTML]], [[JPEG]], [[XBM]], [[X PixMap|XPM]]) * [[E-mail client]]s (e.g. [[Mutt (e-mail client)|Mutt]], [[Pine (e-mail client)|Pine]]) * [[Communications protocol|Protocols]]: [[File Transfer Protocol|FTP]],<ref name="argo user commands">{{Cite web|title=Argo: user commands per mode|url=http://www.w3.org/People/Bos/Argo/doc/Argo.html|publisher=[[World Wide Web Consortium]]|accessdate=27 June 2010|author=[[Bert Bos]]|date=23 November 2007}}</ref> [[Gopher (protocol)|gopher]],<ref name="argo user commands" /> [[Hypertext Transfer Protocol|HTTP]],<ref name="argo user commands" /> [[Network News Transfer Protocol|NNTP]],<ref name="argo user commands" /> [[Wide area information server|WAIS]],<ref name="argo user commands" /> [[File URI scheme|local files]]<ref name="argo user commands" /> * Graphical navigation
The browser's [[kernel (computer science)|kernel]] depended on the modules to provide such functionality.
==Technical== The browser was run on [[HP-UX]] and used dynamic loading to support its applets(plugins).
